title: First SLS launch remains on schedule for late August
summary: Preparations for the first flight of the Space Launch System remain on track for a liftoff as soon as Aug. 29, NASA officials said Aug. 3.

title: With solar arrays now operational, Lucy’s got some shimmering to do
summary: We've still got to wait three years before the first asteroid flyby.

title: Lockheed invests in Xona’s GPS-alternative constellation
summary: Startup Xona Space Systems has raised around $15 million for its proposed navigation constellation, including funds from GPS satellite maker Lockheed Martin’s venture capital arm.

title: SpaceX working to improve fairing recovery for continued success
summary: After a year of solid success with Falcon 9 fairing recovery and reuse, SpaceX has once again started tinkering with the recovery operation.

title: Russia wants a better look at what America’s newest spy satellite can do
summary: Spying in space does not violate any international norms.

title: ESA ends efforts to recover Sentinel-1B
summary: The European Space Agency is ending efforts to restore operations of the Sentinel-1B radar imaging satellite that malfunctioned more than half a year ago and will instead move up the launch of a replacement.

title: Slingshot acquires Numerica’s space-tracking business and UK space data firm Seradata
summary: Slingshot Aerospace announced Aug. 3 it has acquired Numerica’s space-tracking business and UK space data firm Seradata

title: Momentus deploys additional satellites from Vigoride tug
summary: Momentus has deployed additional satellites from its first space tug that encountered technical problems shortly after its launch in May and is moving forward with a second launch later this year.

title: ULA’s Atlas 5 rocket moved to launch pad with U.S. military missile warning satellite
summary: United Launch Alliance’s next Atlas 5 rocket rolled out to its launch pad Tuesday at Cape Canaveral for a fiery blastoff at dawn Thursday with a U.S. military missile warning satellite.

title: Biden to sign chips bill in a boost for satellite supply chains
summary: A bill that would give $52 billion in subsidies to U.S. chip makers promises to galvanize domestic production, although it will take time to alleviate a semiconductor shortage that has been delaying satellite projects.
